trip: The Tubo area is deep within the narrow lanes of Zaragoza’s Old Town. Many tapas bars and restaurants are located here. For a lively, authentic experience, head here after 8pm as that’s when things really start to get busy.
Get lost in Zaragoza’s old town stopping in some of the tapas bar you will find in this laberinto. Enjoy!
Buzzing atmosphere,bars drinks, tapas, people. This street is always busy, lunchtime, early or late supper. Tiny winding street with lots of places to stop.. if you can find a corner to squeeze into!
there are many restaurants which are open 20.00. there are no table service. i suggest to have one drink and tapas in each place and try as much as tapas place you can .
Great area of the old town with tapas bars lined along the narrow streets creating a wonderful atmosphere. Tried a couple of new tapas Chompi and Huevos Rotos which I enjoyed.

We went here as part of a foodie tour and the area was vibrant with lots of great energy and a large number of interesting places serving tapas. Definitely worth a visit to experience the food culture in Zaragoza.

Great spot to grab a tapas and local beer (Ambar) or wines of Aragon (la Broja, Carinena and Sommos.... - darn I don't remember the rest of the name). Friendly people, fun atmosphere and super food and wine. This place is meant to sample at various spots and enjoy the
Went for tapas at a couple restaurants in the area. Los rotos is a good place to start. Greatly recommended!

El Tubo it is called like that because it is an area of very narrow streets in the city center of Zaragoza, like a “tube”. It is very known because it is dull of small bars and restaurants serving the best tapas and meals in town. The ambience is incredible. Locals choose to

Friday night, 9.30 and busy. Very charming waitress helped us choose with a mixture of Spanglish & pointing. We had a seafood skillet and grilled vegetables with Iberico ham. Accompanied by red wine and a beer. Delicious food and a buzzy atmosphere.

We prefer to enjoy this area during the daytime, at night it can be too busy for our taste but it's a must visit, particularly if you've never been there. There are lots of places to choose from, impossible to list them all and unfair to recommend just one or two. All kinds of

You have to have a meal/dinner here if in Zaragoza. the staff are fabulous in every respect. The tapas dishes are served up in a timely fashoin and are worth every penny. A truly great place to eat and to enjoy the moment. There is a no reservation policy , so take note !

We enjoyed a few tapas and vinos in the street. The quality of the food on offer differs between bars, so choose carefully. But it's all good value anyway. The only problem is the guys going around selling tat. This is common in other places of course but they were a bit

Pictures can be deceiving, we went there and found out that is a few streets with a very few small shops, coffee shops and restaurants; if you are thinking about large cities old town experience THIS IS NOT THE PLACE. Fotos podrian enganar, la parte central de la ciudad es
Get lost in this labyrinth to taste the best local food. Do not get stuck in one of them and get one tapa in each of them. Enjoy

Zaragoza is less known than other places in Spain for food, but El Tubo is amazing! A whole block full of lovely tapas places of excellent level and very affordable price. Zaragoza is also a lovely little town with lots of historic heritage, so definitely recommended and worth
Packed with teens...not my style. Too many loud smoking drinking party seekers. Very crowded. I suppose this s what party seekers are looking for.

...the restaurants were closed until quite late. This is not a problem, if you travel around in summer or early autumn, but in springtime, when evening grow dark and cold early, you would prefer to eat earlier. Therefore, spring is not the ideal time to visit Zaragoza's historic

If you're looking for a great place to hang out, try some some tapas and taste local wines and cañas, you need to go there. Plenty of bars and restaurants. Narrow streets. Some neat "tag" art. You have to see it if ever you visit Zaragoza!
I recommend this place if you want to chill out drinking cold drinks, El Tubo is by la plaza del Pilar & basílica del Pilar, so its location is great. I found El Tubo very narrow, ain't very cozy
Not my cup of tea, narrow, crowded, touristy with high prices and such just a nep but well fortunately we are all different
Everybody speaks in Zaragoza abot this zone wich is a place to taste ·tapas" We tried 3 different bars and I didn´t find they were palatable

If all you want is to experience the atmosphere,strolling through the streets,and spending an hour or so,stretching your legs seeing the sights then it will be ok. Some streets are tidy,some not so. If you want more,ie drinks / food,be careful ! Prices are generally not
If you want the night live in Zaragoza this is the place, hundreds of people circulating in this small streets where you can find a bar to eat some tapas and cañas.
I love old areas of cities like this where you get a jumble of small streets with lively collectons of people milling about and a wide selection of bars and tapas restaurants.

Nice walk amongst bars and restaurants. Try eating some tapas in a few different bars. Do not miss a dish with “miga” (bread crumbs) as it is traditional , they serve either with grapes, eggs or chorizo.
If one want to hang out going some tapas bar hoping or just having some local wine and cañas this is he place to go in Zaragoza

this part of the city, is a place worth visiting. Streets full of restaurants and cafes were you can find all type of cuisines, not only tapas, but also international dishes, if you want something else, besides tapas or pinxchos.. we went twice to this part of town and found
Stop in Zaragoza is great to eat in the streets of the tube. The atmosphere of the terraces is second to none. And you can taste the Spanish cuisine at very good prices.

To get at the heart of the city center in Zaragoza, you have to visit El Tubo--the narrow alleys full of restaurants, cafes, bars, quaint little plazas and shops. Some parts are cleaner than others, and some establishments more reputable than others, but if you want tapas, El

Do not miss to go to The Tube in the evening: even if you do not drink some glasses of wine and taste different tapas...But: if you find time, go to this street again in the morning - you will feel a very big difference.

A lot of small restaurants/bars that offer a wide range of tapas and drinks. Tapas are Spanish traditional and international too. It's a real gastronomic experience and it's recommended to do at least 2 or 3 stopovers in 2 or 3 different restaurants. Love the tapas with foie

Plenty of small places for tapas, or more formal meals. All sorts of foods, spanish traditional, and International. Also fussion. Bars are in narrow streets, with a wonderful atmosphere. Expect being a bit crowd in peak hours and weekends / special celebration days, but that is

The El Tubo is a great culinary street and gastronomic experience. When there visit El Hormiguero Azul for the best Seafood Tapas amongst the best I have experienced in my many travels throughout Spain

If you are looking for food then head to the old town of Zaragoza. Small windy interesting streets comprise this area lined with dozens of restaurants, bars and tapas. This is also close to where much of the historic center lies filled with churches and museums.

A delight of narrow inter- connection streets in just a small area, Seems like every other building a bodega, tapas bar or narrow fronted and deep restaurant, Quite acceptable just to stop dead and greet a friend, so human navigation important. So narrow in places barrel outside

It was hard to decide which restaurant in El Tubo to choose. Our advice pick several! Each have their own distinct Pinxos which are delicious. Many have Bodegas in the bottom floor. A fun and lively place to enjoy while visiting beautiful Zaragoza.
Very lively neighborhood, fun to walk there at night for a drink and tapas or dinner. Make sure to spend some time there!
Everyday the district is full of People. Laughing, drinking and eating. The athmosphere is relaxating. It's full of tapas bars in small streets.
Narrow small streets with dozens of tapas restaurants with different food, crowded inside and outside in the evenings, very lively

A warren of narrow pedestrianised streets featuring tapas bars, boutiques and graffiti. No visit to Zaragoza is complete without a wander around El Tubo. Mostly closed during the day, becomes animated in the evenings.
Nice to stroll around and eat and drink with, and like the locals. Lots of restaurants and typical "stand up" tapas bars

We had great expectations of El Tubo based on reviews online, but it turned out to be just a block of small streets with lots of touristy bars, restaurants and shops like you find in many Spanish cities. That said, it is cozy enough and there are some nice places for eating and
In the historic centre, Dotted with shops selling nice souvenirs. Nice walk to spend some time looking around lot of shops and eataries
Even in February, El Tubo is the place to go for tapas in Zaragosa. We stayed fairly close and walking to El Tubo was easy

Pretty nice place, like a separate quarter where have fun and eat and drink till late in the night, when other restaurant are closed. You can feel the Spanish life here, the soul of the city. It’s a must

A very good area for drinks, I was there a night for some drinks and the atmosphere was good, several places even late at night, good calm people inside the bars and good quality drinks. The extra of feeling safe at 4:00 a.m. is also of a lot help.
Great place for lunch (1pm to 4pm) or dinner (7.30 to late). Always a crawl from place to place with a drink. Great fun in each place......Just go wherever looks good to you. Totally safe.

El Tubo area is located in the old part of the city with narrow and very DIRTY pedestrian streets. Really nothing to do and see there only unless you want to eat. A lot of small tapas bars and restaurants that close during the day for many hours approx. from 3 to 7 pm. Avoid

El Tubo is comprised of narrow streets filled with Tapas bars. All types, some better than others. While most of the dissatisfied reviews concentrate on the quality of the over priced food and slow service I think people primarily come here to hang out, people watch and

This area of town is a must visit for anyone going to Zaragoza. Our guide, Jorge, (see my review of Foodie and Tours) took us there and we were amazed at the variety of great food and wine that was on offer. So go, have a wander, bring a big appetite and don't drive as you'll

This is supposed to be the street of food but it's actually more than one street and it twists and turns and branches off but it's all good, with different food offerings. It helps to have a local take you but even on your own you shouldn't have any problems seeing what's

In the heart of the old town, el tubo is a warren of streets lined with cafes, tapas bars and restaurants. Some better than others, but do what the Spanish do and try a few bars each night to find your favourite.
If you have to choose an area for "taping" this is the place to go, lots of bars with lots of people

The heart for tapas and drinks. El Tubo - wide selection of different places for tapas and drinks. Great atmosphere all around. All the locals and tourists come here. If you visit Zaragoza, “ El Tubo” is a must!

We really enjoyed this area in the evening. This is a fun place to eat, drink, and people watch. We visited a number of the bars; and had our version of a progressive dinner – we stopped at several places to try the Tapas.

El Tubo is a maze of small alleys and streets packed with bars and restaurants. It seems to be packed with locals as well as tourists almost every night and is a great place to get tapas and just soak up the atmosphere

This is the place to go for drinks and Tapas in Zaragoza. Although empty until around 7pm it starts buzzing later in the evening. The only exception to this being on Mondays when I found the bars staying half empty.
This area is well worth a visit. It is buzzing at night and feels safe and fun. Loads of restaurants and bars to choose from, and some great tapas. Great people, good food and lots of choice.

Wandered down these lanes and although quite interesting the places looked a bit grubby and would probably get a 1 from UK standards. Many nicer places to eat in Zaragoza, try the croquet place for instance.
This is what Spain is all about. Drink, eat, talk, laugh and just have fun. We stopped in 2 tapas places and both the food and drinks were good and not expensive.
Relaxed atmosphere, numerous tapas bars and many people eating, drinking and above all socialising. Must visit when in Z.
There are endless tapa bars with their own unique take on the crocheta. On Thursdays you will find over 30 bars that have 1/2 price tapas and drinks. Fun to get the locals' recommendations.

A small section of the town with very narrow streets , lined with bars and restaurants. Some are offering 'ruin gardens' (like Budapest or Berlin) excellent for a drink and chillout. Food is greasy but hey its good!
This area is an absolute MUST in Zaragoza. There are about 25 different tapas places in this area. Go several times to sample as many as you can. The choices were endless.
A must have in this location is a selection of tapas from one of the many tapas bars. Great atmosphere and interesting culture.

El Tubo is a very popular zone in the center of Zaragoza. In fact, it is located in the oldtown and it is the place, where a lot of people go out in the weekend. It is full of bars and restaurants and it is the best activity to do at night: go to some bars to taste a lot of
There is something enticing about tiny lanes that curve and twist. The fact that they are cool and shady is a bonus in hot weather. There are some little gems in these lanes.
Zaragoza is the capital of Aragon. Very nice old town center with many bars, restaurants, interesting stores.
Small but interesting a vibrant old part of the city. Rammed full of bars, restaurants and small shops. Buzzing Friday and Saturday nights.

It was a hot day which provides a perfect summer evening (with full moon thrown in). The alley ways were packed with diners of all ages creating a fantastic atmosphere. Tapas of all types and varying prices are on offer and all we tried was delicious. Nit a lot of English spoken

El Tubo is a must if you want to get a sense of the locals' Zaragoza. Narrow, winding streets filled with bars, and tapas and other restaurants, makes you feel you are in a village and not a city. Each bar seems to have a speciality to differentiate them from the others - a
So many places to find Tapas in this area! We arrived later in the day after getting off the train. Many places do take siesta from 4-8pm but there were a few that remained open.

These narrow streets and old buildings stand since the 1800"s, numerous tapas bars and small business , Casa Lac is the oldest running restaurant in Spain, open non stop since 1825, and the food is very good too.
Packed with different types of tapas bars and restaurants, this old part of Zaragoza is the place to head for your culinary needs. Great fun.
Lots of restaurants, with great variety of tapas and wines and vibrant atmosphere. Highly recommended for those wanting to have a delicious taste of Spanish food and wines.

Great section in the old town to go for drinks and tapas. Many bars serving tapas on the street and a great vibe for hanging out and enjoying the town. Great for people watching and enjoying a drink with friends or family.
Certainly worth visiting when in Zaragoza but it gets hectic in the evening & bars can be hit & miss. Had a few tapas along the route, but had nicer meals & tapas away from El Tubo.

After our visit to the Cathedral we walked the narrow and charming streets of old town Zaragoza, El Tubo is probably one of the narrowest, with bars to stop for a glass of wine a tapa or a beer, visit specialty shops, delicious cafes for crepes and hot chocolate!

This is an absolute warren of narrow streets and lanes, packed with bars, most also appeared to serve tapas. The area comes alive after 6pm, when it is not difficult to spot the popular establishments, as they tend to have crowds extending into the adjacent roadways . A few

I don't usually write a review if I don't like a place but this area gets such rave reviews and I really don't understand why. By writing this I feel like the boy who said the Emperor wasn't wearing any clothes. The narrow streets are strewn with graffiti, the more open spaces
The tubo with its harmful streets, restaurants and bars is the ideal place for tapas with friends or in family. Nice atmosphere for young and less young adults.

Yes, if you are in Zaragoza, you should definitely plan to spend an evening tapas hopping in El Tubo. The narrow streets are atmospheric, and you can follow your own impulses or ask locals for their suggestions on the best tapas to be had. There are many bars, and choices to

This is a really interesting area, in Zaragozza's Old Town, to have a stroll around and a drink or two. The streets are narrow, which adds to the atmosphere, and there are loads of little bars. The only negative is that, in terms of food, it did not cater very well for
Zaragoza is not a town for tapas. After traveling through the Basque country, the culinary scene here is very disappointing. El Tubo was nice for the area, but poor compared to other areas of Spain.
A must to roam around this alley as the restaurants here are amazing.....Lunch or dinner...you'll get whatever you want
My boyfriend and I visited various places in the tubo over the weekend we were visiting. Each place we went to was great! And very economical. Good during the day or at night
This street is full of bars with tapas. You definitely get a feel of city life in Zaragoza. The only thing that if your hungry stick to the hours of Spain to eat. Everything closes at 4 pm

You must go here to eat. El Tubo is an area of short narrow streets with restaurants and bars on both sides. There are many different types of restaurants and places to get food. If you are visiting, look for tapas. Some of the restaurants specialize in one type of food. For

There many places to choose from we started in the mushroom place, la cueva de Aragon. Then moved to a creative taps place, sorry I can't remember the name, but it's just a little bit further up the street. Nibbling and drinking great atmosphere! Well recommended. Late nights
It's a maze of narrow street full of bars and tapas restaurants. You should come in Friday or Saturday evening to experience the bustling Zaragoza night life and to eat, drink and laugh. Salud!!

It is one of the classic and best areas in town to go for tapas. It is a must in the town. Only, beware, in Zaragoza, tapas are not for free with the drinks. And in some bars, they are like high cuisine in small dish, so not cheap

An excellent place to have a bar crawl and taste all the culinary charm of Saragoza. We walked through all the neighborhood and every corner was a pleasant surprise. Fantastic vibe and welcoming people everywhere, I certainly recommend it.

Great place close to all the shopping, street cars, taxis. Lively on a Wednesday night, unbelievable! Well the tapas were out of sight, shrimps, sardines, peperonica, everything on a small piece of bread, and artsy too. Great time going to several places.

A nice area to stroll around especially at night, with lots of bars, shops and interesting buildings. We visited this area to do a tapas trail and must say that it was very disappointing compared to other cities, many much smaller. The number of places that provided interesting
Nice city. Very clean. Lots of restaurants and shops. Many different types of food to choose from. The river is near and is a great place to walk or visit one of the restaurants.

hi visited el tubo for 3 nights sunday/monday and tuesday in november on the wettest 3 nights of the year which meant it was very quiet and a lot of the bars stayed closed and the bars we visited were all reasonably quiet,enjoyed the area and could not fault any of the bars we
Absolutely lovely city centre, with so much to do and see. Churches, cathederals, roman ruins, fab shops, and lively bars and restaurants, at only 50-75% of the cost of Barcelona. Genuine Spain!
Charming area full of great bars and restaurants with lots of atmosphere. Lovely street, many great places to eat or have a snack.

Old centre buzzes at night with a huge variety of Tapas bars available. There are so many choices of Tapas it is best to take the smaller portions to try as much as you can. At less than 2 euros each it is a great way to find the food you like and if tempted you can order a
This was my favorite area of Zaragoza....tons of cafes and beautiful buildings...also some tasteful graffiti art.

Great place for a night out with friends, family or for couples. Streets can be a bit rowdy but that just adds to the fun. Each bar has their own specialities so have a bite and a drink at each one, then move on! Most of the cold tapas on the bar seem to have been prepared in

We love people watching so this is a great place for us - grab a seat outside, order a beer and watch so many walks of life walk by. Most of the tubo bars sell Ambar (the beer brewed locally) or wine (and of course random spirits and soft drinks). It is quite cheap (compared to
So many place to try in this fascinating labyrinth of classically Spanish narrow alleys. Would have liked more time in the city to test of few more bars.
Its definitely a must do in Zaragoza, always trending topic, great food options and beer always at a hand

We begin our exploration of Zaragoza walking down el tubo and spent 4 wonderful hours moving from one tapas bar to the next. Repeated this tonight from the other direction and planning a return tomorrow. The tapas is amazing, the raciones enticing, the drinks generous and very

El Tubo is a true classic in the city center of Zaragoza. In a quite narrow street, you will find a series of small bars serving tasty tapas. The first ones in the street only serve one specific tapas alongside an artisanal beer. It's one of great experience to try while you are

We arrived on a Sunday evening with the vague idea that El Tubo was a good area for pintxos and wine. It's a maze of bars and restaurants offering a bewildering variety food and many fine wines. Some of the restaurants look romantic with simple tables and chairs in the shells
It was very pleasant to walk around the old town's streets at night and have drinks and delicious tapas.
Very nice labyrinth of small streets packed with tapas bars doing great specialties. We recommand Humani and Casa Juanito ... Great places !

We thought this area was actually a place to eat but in fact it is LOTS of places to eat. They all look great and are quite affordable for travelling students. There is an old, authentic feel to the area which adds to the very pleasant atmosphere.

This is definitely the place to eat, drink and be merry in Zaragoza. Lots of bars, great tapas and a warm atmosphere make these narrow lanes and alleys great fun. There is a family atmosphere and the bar staff are generally very hospitable - even to idiots like me whose Spanish

If you aren't really sure what you are in the mood for, head to El Tubo around tapas hour and stroll around until you find something you like. Choose one of the many filled with Spaniards out enjoying the evening. Great people watching, great place to hop around and try food

nice walk at night, the small streets of this areas are crowded with people enjoying good drink, food and talks in the street, just the beautiful life of Spain. We had excellent tapas and wonderful wine in some place and another, the service is just so nice, effective and

This is how a party city should be. El Tubo is the old Roman heart of Zaragoza, all narrow streets and alleys. No shops to distract you from the business of FUN! Just bars and clubs and restaurants, pulsing with heat and life. To pass the time durng the day there are great
So many tapas bars, so many delicious things to taste and try. So much fun and a great way to spend an evening or two
Dive in. So many bars. Don't look for diversity. This is a local scene. Some places will be average, some will delight. But you won't fail to catch the excitement of an evening.
We hit up several little places for tapas and drinks. Almost everyone was super friendly and helpful about what to try.
I had a great time in this zone of the town. The spanish cuisine is fantastic and in this zone you can try many difrentes tipes. Is a great zone for tapas y vino! Enjoy!
It's the place where people goes after work to have a quick snack or tapas ! Great ambience and food ! We spent time with friends and it was really nice !
Order a beer and Champi at the bar, it's ready in a minute and share and enjoy! Fantastic idea, which could only exist here, you must try it.
you just take small glass of vine 2 tapas and go to next bar, I just love it. atmosphere and food its wonderful and the street its really cute

This historic part of the city is full of fantastic tapas bars, restaurants and cafes. There are so many that are good, the whole evening can be spent wandering from one to another, especially the tapas bars
With its narrow, cobble-stoned streets lined in little shops and tapas bars, this neighbourhood is clearly the heart and soul of Zaragoza.
Crazy place at night, lots of small restaurants, all crowded with people drinking beer, eating tapas, enjoying themselves, a true fiesta in the middle of the city!!

A perfect place to wander on a spring evening. Lots of people around, so it felt safe even in the narrowest laneways. Many locals only speak a little English, if any, but they are so friendly and helpful that it isn't hard to get by. Wine is cheap and food is great.

Go and try the tapas. Just move from bar to bar. We went with young children (3 under 9) and I have to say, many of the places are a lot more child friendly than I expected. The standing can be annoying for little legs so you may have to miss the big draw places where it's

We looked for this place based on some TripAdvisor recommendations and found it very interesting to visit. This is the old narrow part of town with shops and restaurants. We found a nice places to eat (be warned that many restaurant have odd hours and are closed certain days, so
A place where you can go for diferent sorts of local tapas with real homemade flavours my tip go for bocadillo de calamares
Choose carefully but can get mostly anything...best for 'going tapas' Not great if your not a smoker when sitting outside. Good fun...folk chatting...drinking and eating. Good for all the family.
have one drink & one tappas at each place & eat at 5 or 7 different restaurants - best food in town for sure
You can start in El Tubo and eat for 4 hours on a row, just hopping from one bar to an other. This is the real typicaly food from Aragón.
Lots of great Tapas Bars and great place to spend an evening either in a elegant restaurant or a crowded bar drinking and eating

On our first day in Zaragoza, we went looking for El Tubo thinking that it was a definite cafe or bar. Later, we found out that it is a district or an area, where there are different bars and cafes serving tapas. This is the place to go, if you want to experience the Spanish
And find some hidden treasures in the restaurants and tapas bars herein. DISREGARD the sex shop you see on first entering the Tubo, and persist. Many lovely places nearby.
Typical european old city centre, narrow alleyways with many restaurants and little tavernas serving a varied sellection of food and drink.Great to walk around and witness the buzz of the place
We went walking around El Tubo and trying out several places for their food. It's a must do when in Zaragoza!
Though it is a small town, el Tubo offers many options for a great nightlife. From typical Spanish tapas bars to modern bars and cafés, restaurants and clubs!

El tubo is the place to go in Zaragoza for anything related to great tapas and drinks in the late evening (starting 9pm). You will find so many choices there that it might take you a while to identify the best place fo you to go. My personal favorite is El CHAMPI where you get

If you really want to know how eating tapas is like, go to El Tubo. You can have many delicious montaditos and other great finger food along with a nive glass of wine or beer. Be warned that true tapas bars have no seats though.

Typical Spanish tapas bars - open warm and inviting. the tapas were mostly fish or meat based and of good quality. Staff friendly and helpful - not much English spoken though so you need a smattering of Spanish. A good place to visit.

I was amazed at this area of Zaragoza. We arrived at our hotel Saturday around 2.00pm. We then went for a walk and stumbled into the area called El Tubo. We had heard about it when we booked the hotel. The atmosphere was amazing. There seemed to be a Tapas bar every few metres

El Tubo is a fantastic area of Zaragoza and should not be missed if you are in the city. It is a warren of narrow side streets with countless tapas bars and restaurants. The atmosphere is tremendous and the quality of the tapas is world famous.

Best area for tapas and wine in Zaragoza. Enjoy the best eats and drinks in a medieval and historic area of Zaragoza. Composed of interlinked narrowed streets forming Clusters of Bars packed with people. the people talking outside the bars, socialising, smoking, etc is a classic
Narrow medieval streets house many restaurants offering local and wider cuisines. Sit outside or inside, stand outside, enjoy the atmosphere.

This is the tapas district and then some. On a weekday night, the area sings with life. If you don't want to eat or drink anything, it's still worth walking around. No one thinks of Zaragoza as the city that never sleeps, but it sure felt that way. The tapas and wine are

A wonderful 'pub crawl' with tasting all of the tapas in this area! This is the best of Zaragoza and make sure you try as many tapas as you can! But don't start before 8 pm because everything is closed before then! And dinner starts a few hours later...

This area in old Zaragoza is ideal for wandering ! It has the old maybe 90 year old theatre type show which for many visitors may feel from a different age. An age when gentlemen would enter with raincoats. But really it can be a true experience. It is called El Plata and is

It is just great to walk around in the old city centre. What is even more beautiful is that you find Street Art all over the old city centre and the suburb San Jose. You can find art on the walls of different buildings. It is thé most beautiful and surprising thing in Zaragoza.
An alleyway leading to a square, with Tapas bars galore. Good, but not quite as welcoming or appealing as the equivalent in Pamplona.

We were underwhelmed by this area - we expected it to be busy and lively, and full of different places to eat which would cater to different tastes/diets. It was rather quiet and we did not find anywhere suitable for dinner.

It's been over 40 years since I was in Zaragoza. I was first there as a young hippie student scraping along, and now I'm part of the establishment. The 'Tubos' were a collection of bad bars and restaurants that we frequented because it was cheap and for the excitement. Now it
The typical place to have tapas and drinks at night. Not as good as the same type from some other provinces in Spain, but good enough

El Tubo in Zaragoza is not to be missed. Everything in this city is great and at a great price and El Tubo is no exception. There were fancier places but "100 Montaditos" was my favorite place for tapas and great Tinto de Verano.

They say that Zaragoza is the tapas capital centre of Spain, and El Tubo is the epicentre! You cannot go wrong here in any of the establishments. Prices are cheap, particularly with the current state of the Euro. Try the huevos rotos, unbelievable!
nice little streets with lots of tapas restaurants and bars ! big diversity of tapas ! at night its pretty boring as they all close at around 00.00

We discovered that a lot of places/attractions/shops/bars etc have quite set opening times which don't really fit in with our personal timetables. A lot of the bars close around 3 or 4pm and then open later at around 7.30. We tend to get out and about for 9:30 and then stay

You are spoilt for choice here, with numerous tapas bars crowded into the narrow streets. Busy & fun in the evenings, you just need to follow your instincts & choose one bar you like the look of. We found one located inside a ruin, open to the sky but with the four high walls

'El Tubo' is the place to be to experience all that Spain has to offer in terms of not only food but especially the joyful vitality of Spanish life. The small area located in the backstreets of the Alfonso shopping street is a labyrinth of not just gastronomic delights but

El Tubo is located in the centre of the city a short walk off Calle de Coso, it is a collection of alleyways with bars and restaurants where you can sample Spanish hospitality, tapas, local wines, fun, fun, fun. Go early in the Spanish evening if you don't want it to be too

So many restaurants, so many different wines, truely a great place to experience the nightlife combined with great food and ambiance. You have so many different restaurants and specialties to choose from, you won´t be able to decide where to go.

text.wiki:
The Solans House (Spanish, Casa Solans) is an Art Nouveau palace in Saragossa, Spain. It is also known as Casa de los Azulejos (House of Tiles).
Built between 1918 and 1921 to a design by the architect Miguel Ángel Navarro Pérez, it was commissioned by Juan Solans, an industrialist. In 1926, the owner died, and it became the property of the widow and nephew of the deceased in equal parts. After a long period of abandonment, the building was restored, and was used as the headquarters of the United Nations Office of Support to the Water Decade until 2015.


== References ==
